awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Wearable System for Stress Management via Real Time Stress Tracking and Biofeedback
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is creating a tool for police officers and other service members who are expected to perform their job duties under high stress.  This Phase 1 project seeks to develop a technology that creates stress scores and alerts users when they are in “red zones” for decision making based on physiological monitoring via a wearable sensor unit. The initial target market segment for this technology is the ~$1 billion law enforcement market as there is a high need for tools that can help de-escalate situations and potentially improve the use-of-force decisions. The pain points of acute stress impacting decision-making have been validated in military and professional athletic markets as well.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to develop a wearable technology that uses skin conductivity to measure stress and alert users via vibrational feedback. This Phase 1 project proposes to: (1) run a pilot study on police officers to collect skin conductance data during scenario training, (2) build machine learning artificial intelligence (AI) models with a high predictive accuracy of poor decision making using this data, (3) determine ideal sensor location and build a custom wearable strap attachment, (4) develop the mobile application to build a data visualization interface for officers and trainers, and (5) test the effectiveness of delivering vibrational feedback during decision making of officers using the prototype. The successful conclusion of Phase 1 may lead to a hardware-software prototype that measures the police officers' emotional stress using a skin conductance signal, then alerts the user via vibrational feedback when they are in a heightened level of stress.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Law enforcement officers have to make split second life or death decisions on a daily basis. However they do not receive sufficient training as to how to self-regulate and optimally apply their tactics under stress. The goal of this NSF SBIR Phase 1 project is to develop a minimal viable product (MVP) that trains police officers for self-regulation by monitoring their stress levels in real-time and offering them feedback and interventions to improve emotional control. In order to accomplish this goal Neurosmart collaborated with training divisions of multiple law enforcement agencies across the country. The team collected physiological data indicating officer stress levels as well as subjective reports of officer performance from their commanders during in-service training. The team then developed algorithms to predict poor performance from the physiological data. The team also designed user friendly proprietary scores to show each officer how well they regulate their nerves during stressful situations. Finally the team implemented the live streaming, stress score calculation and the model that alerts officers and trainers of poor performance on an Android mobile application. The application can be used by both individual police officers and their trainers. The wearable stress tracker and the Neurosmart application are now being pilots by multiple police agencies across the United States. 

 

The intellectual merit of this work is the development of novel algorithms that link physiological signals to real world performance events. A lot of the wearables currently on the market are 'data dumps' with no implications for actual performance which lead to diminished engagement by the users over time. Neurosmart's algorithms are designed to learn from the user and improve their predictability over time as well as provide insights for improvement to the user. In addition, there are very few studies looking at police officer physiology during training and how stress impacts their decision making during critical incidents. Neurosmart generated novel data and insights in this field, which it has shared with participating agencies. The company has plans to publish these results in aggregate anonymised fashion for the benefit of the law enforcement community. This will have implications for police officer training as well as investigations and departmental policy changes. 


Neurosmart established key partnerships with law enforcement agencies throughout the award period and also participated in the NSF's I-Corps customer discovery program to understand the law enforcement market. The team integrated the feedback they received into their product and product roadmap. Adoption of Neurosmart technology by law enforcement training academies and agencies will transform the way police officers are trained in the United States. Our technology specifically trains officers to regulate their physiology and to make better decisions under stress. This will result in reduction of use of force errors, as well as improvement in officer wellbeing and decision making. For departments, a better equipped police force means less errors on patrol, less legal fees, less days missed due to injuries and better recruitment. Ultimately use of our technology will improve law enforcement agencies relationships with the communities they serve.
